title: How to Password Protect a Microsoft Excel Spreadsheet

steps.title: Open a project in Microsoft Excel.
steps.content: Open a project in Microsoft Excel. If needed, you can create a new spreadsheet . [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source Microsoft Excel is available to download on Windows and Mac . You can also use the online web version at https://www.office.com/ .

steps.title: Click File.
steps.content: Click File . This will be at the top-left corner of the window, next to Home . [2] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source A new page will open.

steps.title: Click Info.
steps.content: Click Info . You can find this in the left panel. [3] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Click Protect Workbook.
steps.content: Click Protect Workbook . This is the first tile of the Info tab. [4] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source A drop-down menu will open.

steps.title: Set as Read-Only (optional).
steps.content: Set as Read-Only (optional). If you want to prevent accidental changes from others when you share your workbook , you can set the workbook as "Read-Only". Keep in mind that others will be able to change this mode if they choose. Click Always Open Read-Only in the drop-down menu. You'll see an icon of a pencil and cancel symbol underneath Protect Workbook .

steps.title: Click Encrypt with Password.
steps.content: Click Encrypt with Password . This will be below Always Open Read-Only . A pop-up box will open.

steps.title: Enter a password and click OK.
steps.content: Enter a password and click OK . Keep in mind you won't be able to reset or recover the password if you forget it. Be sure to use a password you can remember . [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Re-enter the password and click OK.
steps.content: Re-enter the password and click OK . Input the same password as the previous step. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source You should now see a lock and key icon underneath Protect Workbook .

steps.title: Close the workbook.
steps.content: Close the workbook. If you're prompted to save, be sure to save. When you open the workbook again, you'll be asked to enter in your password.

steps.title: Open a project in Microsoft Excel.
steps.content: Open a project in Microsoft Excel. If needed, you can create a new one.

steps.title: Click Review.
steps.content: Click Review . This is the tab at the top, next to Data . [7] X Research source

steps.title: Click Protect Workbook.
steps.content: Click Protect Workbook . This is in the "Changes" section.

steps.title: Check the "Structure" box.
steps.content: Check the "Structure" box. If you have also set up specific windows within the file, check the pertinent box as well.

steps.title: Type in your password.
steps.content: Type in your password. Be sure to use a password you can remember, as you won't be able to reset it. You may need to do this twice.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . Your Excel file is now password-protected. When you open it, you'll be asked to input your password.
